video-config.troubleshootingIntro: If you're having any trouble getting your webcam set up, please feel free to contact the Infant Studies Centre at 604-822-6408 or email us at infants@psych.ubc.ca

video-consent.datause: We are primarily interested in your child's reactions to the videos and sounds. A research assistant will watch your video after to examine where your child is looking on the screen.
video-consent.payment: There are no known risks to participating in studies like ours where your child is accompanied by you and/or a researcher. The procedure used in this study has been shown to be safe. While there are no direct benefits, many families enjoy participating in these activities. After we complete the study, you will be able to access any resulting publications on our website and see what you and your child helped us find out about speech and language development. Our annual newsletter can also be found on our website (https://infantstudies.psych.ubc.ca/). You will receive an e-mail with a link to a $10 gift certificate to Amazon for participating in this study.
video-consent.purpose: In this activity, we are interested in understanding how young infants learn word labels. Are words exclusive to certain people and objects? Or can they be extended to other objects in the world? For example, when they hear 'mommy', will they only look at the photograph of you, or will they look at someone else?
video-consent.PIContact: Dr. Janet F. Werker at jwerker@psych.ubc.ca
video-consent.procedures: First, you will provide verbal consent by recording a video following steps 2 through 4 on the right side of this page (please make sure you read the entire consent form before doing so!). During this activity, your child will see photographs of different people and objects, such as hands and feet (including your own!). We are interested in where your child is looking on the screen in response to the sounds that they hear. Your child’s looking behaviour will be video-recorded for subsequent observation by a research assistant.

additional_segments.text: At the end of the study, you will be asked to complete a survey about your child's language exposure, early vocabulary development, and ethnic background.
additional_segments.title: Language survey

additional_segments.text: Lookit is a U.S. organization and all information gathered from the website is stored on servers based in the U.S. Therefore, your video recordings are subject to U.S. laws, such as the US Patriot Act. This act allows authorities access to the records of internet service providers. If you choose to participate in this study, you understand that your video recording will be stored and accessed in the USA. The security and privacy policy for Lookit can be found at the following link: https://lookit.mit.edu/privacy/.
additional_segments.title: US Patriot Act Disclosure

additional_segments.text: If, upon review of your stored video, a researcher were to observe or hear of an incident involving abuse and/or neglect of a child, please be advised that the researcher must, by law, report this information to the appropriate authorities.
additional_segments.title: Child Protection Disclosure

additional_segments.text: To comply with guidelines from research funders and journal publications, electronic research data in data sheets from this study may be shared publicly. The shared data sheets will not contain information that can be used to identify you or your child. Once this dataset is made publicly available, you will not be able to withdraw your consent to sharing the data.
additional_segments.title: Data sharing

video-consent.research_rights_statement: If you have any concerns or complaints about your rights as a research participant and/or your experiences while participating in this study, contact the Research Participant Complaint Line in the UBC Office of Research Ethics at 604-822-8598 or if long distance e-mail RSIL@ors.ubc.ca or call toll free 1-877-822-8598 (Ethics Project ID: TODO).

blocks.text: Welcome! This is part 1 of a 2-part study!
blocks.title: Important: your child does not need to be with you for the entire duration of this set-up portion. However, we will need them to be present for a short portion later. Let's go over what will happen!.

blocks.text: In this session, we will collect videos and audio clips from you to be used as part of your personalized study in part 2.

We are interested in how young children learn words for individuals and categories. In this study, we will be measuring your child's understanding of the label for you (e.g. "Mommy"), and the word for something more general, like "hand". To do this, we will ask for you to record a video of you (your baby's mom), a video of your infant's hand, and audio recordings of you saying words to accompany each of these videos.
After recording these videos, you will answer a few final questions. Within 7 days of completing part 1, you will receive an email inviting you and your baby to part 2 of the study!

In a moment, you can preview a silent example of part 2 of the study to see what it would potentially look like. After reading the instructions, you will start the experiment when you and your baby are ready.
Part 1 of the study will take about 20 minutes, while part 2 will take about 5 minutes to complete. Upon finishing both parts of the study you will receive a $10 Amazon gift card.

stimuli.caption: There are two blocks in this study, one were we assess your child's understanding of the label for their mom and one where we assess their understanding of the word "Hand". In the "mom" block, your child will see a video of you paired with either a dog or another woman while hearing the label for you. In the "hand" block, your child will view their own hand paired with another infant's hand or with a foot while hearing the word "hand". These two blocks will appear in random order. Here's an example.

blocks.text: If you'd like to see an example of a video similar to the one your child will be shown in part 2, you can take a look ahead of time now. It's important that you watch this video without your child, so that the videos will still be new to them later. The mom and hand shown here are only examples in your study, your infant will see a video of you (your baby's mom) and their own hand.

video-preview.previewButtonText: Preview a video (my child can't see the screen)

listblocks.text: In the following portion, you will be asked to record a few videos and an audio clips so that we can incorporate it into a personalized version for your child to see in the second part of this study. You will go through instructions to record an audio stream of yourself saying the label of "hand" and "mom" that your child is most likely to recognize, and videos of yourself and your child's hand. We will ask for 2 recordings of each video and audio clip.

Feel free to re-record yourself at each stage if you are not happy with the clip. We will be taking the middle segment of the recordings so please don't worry if the beginning or end show you moving to start or stop the recording.

To end the study early, you may press Control-X and you should see an 'exit' option pop up. You’ll be prompted to note any technical problems you might be experiencing and to select a privacy level for your videos.

debriefing.text:
If you have completed survey, then you are all done part 1 of our study! 

  You and your baby are helping us to better understand how children are connecting sounds in the world to words. Once you have completed the questionnaire, you may then close this window. You will be contacted within the next few days with your link to Part 2! 

  To thank you for your participation, after completing part 2, we will be emailing you a $10 Amazon gift card. If you don't hear from us within a week of completing part 1, feel free to reach out! Each child can only participate once, but if you participate again with another child in the age range, you will receive one gift card per child.
debriefing.title: Thank you for participating in our study!

listblocks.text: In the next part, you will record a 30-second clip of yourself (the child's mother).

This will be a silent clip. We ask that, similar to taking a passport or driving liscense photo, that you don't smile and have a neutral expression. The video will be cropped to only your face and shoulders. We also ask that you wear a dark, solid coloured top, such as a black or dark grey shirt. The background should be a solid colour, such as a wall.
We will be taking certain clips from this video recording and incorporate it in the study.
Please take a look at the example video below.

mediaBlock.text: Once you have played this video, please click the button to go to the next part and try it yourself.

blocks.title: Here you will record a 30-second clip of yourself!

listblocks.text: Here you will record a 30-second clip of yourself (the child's mother).

This will be a silent clip. We ask that, similar to taking a passport or driving liscense photo, that you don't smile and have a neutral expression. The video will be cropped to only your face and shoulders. We also ask that you wear a dark, solid coloured top, such as a black or dark grey shirt. The background should be a solid colour, such as a wall.

blocks.title: Here you will record a 30-second clip of your child's hand!

listblocks.text: Here you will record a 30 second clip of your child's hand.
The most important thing is that the fingers need to be out stretched - their hand can't be in a closed fist or tightly curled.
A good method we have seen in the past is to have the child on the mother's lap, and with one hand hold a piece of paper and the other hold the infant's forearm.
We will be taking a clear still-frame from this and the image in the study will show the infant's hand and wrist. So please hold your infant's forearm.

blocks.title: Here you will record an audio clip of "mom"!

listblocks.text: Here you will record a clip of you saying the label for mom. We ask that you say the word clearly 6 times, with a 3-5 second pause between each word.

This will be the word used most often for the child's mom and the one most likely to be recognize by the child, (e.g. "Mama", "Mommy"). This doesn't necessary have to be in English if that is not what your child hears!
As seen in the example, if you typically use baby speak, please use that tone in these recordings.

blocks.title: Here you will record an audio clip of "hand"!

listblocks.text: Here you will record a clip of you saying "hand". We ask that you say the word clearly 6 times, with a 3-5 second pause between each word.
As seen in the example, if you typically use baby speak, please use that tone in these recordings.

blocks.title: For this final portion, your child does not need to be with you!
